I didn’t expect it to surprise me, but it was actually very well designed. It’s not just empty rooms, but shows and illustrates what every room, every building represents during that active period. The place is also big. It shows what it was like before, and the struggle of Koreans for independence. It explains why Koreans are so patriotic and proud of their own independence. The location of the Xidaemun Criminal Justice Institute’s Historical Hall is good, just off the Dongnimun subway station. I took my teenage son here to see how he felt and saw the history of the Japanese occupation and the resistance that South Korea launched at that time. The day before, we both visited the Seoul History Museum, but the exhibits there were too abstract, and the visit to the Xidaemun Criminal Justice Institute History Museum made all history alive. Walking around this once held political prisoners really can learn and learn a lot about the past. The wish here is that more exhibits and information can be translated into English, and there are tributes from students, workers, pro-democracy activists, but they are also written in Korean, I really hope to translate into English so that we can understand.

The History Museum of Xidaemun Criminal Bureau was built during the Japanese occupation of Korea. It shows the life of prisons and the cruelty of Japanese. It introduces detailed descriptions in Korean, English, Chinese and Japanese. The rooms inside are well protected. In order to make tourists experience and feel better, the torture was restored with wax figures.

The former site of the Xidaemun Criminal Office in Seoul, South Korea, is a very special place. It was once a Korean Criminal Office and has now been transformed into a museum, showing the history and culture of the time. Walk into the Criminal Office, you can see the ancient buildings and facilities and feel the atmosphere. In addition, the Institute of Criminal Affairs has held various exhibitions and activities to give people a deeper understanding of the history of Korea. In short, the former site of the Institute of Criminal Affairs in Xidaemun is a good place to learn about the history and culture of Korea.
It's a great place to experience history. I recommend it

Situated in the West Gate Independent Park, the History Museum of the West Gate Criminal Service Institute is a special museum. As the organ of the Japanese imperialist repression and massacre of revolutionary martyrs at the end of the Korean Empire, the History Museum is the site of the Museum. Liu Kuanshun, known as Joan of Arc of Korea, also died in this prison. In addition to seven cells, you can visit single cells and execution rooms.
In the past, it was quite novel. It was worth seeing. It mainly talked about the Japanese colonial period.
It doesn't feel very famous. Not many people will go there. Of course, the staff are very enthusiastic.
It is the prison history hall during the Japanese occupation of Korea, which is of historic educational significance.
It's depressing to record a history, but it's memorable to the local people.
This is the best place to reflect history. It's very violent and cruel.

This prison is now a museum providing an unflinching and sobering look at how hundreds of independence activists were imprisoned, tortured, and even murdered by the Japanese when Korea was colonized by Japan and under its rule. In addition to allowing visitors to take a look at the prison cells and prison grounds, you will also be able to see the watchtowers and execution room in which many famous Korean independent activists and students were killed. The prison offers a graphic and realistic look at some of the torture methods used so the museum may not be appropriate for the very young. However, everything in the museum provides a harrowing look at a painful part of Korea's history that makes it for an unforgettable and highly recommended visit.
History is the best way for building culture. You will find something incredible inside the buildings. A place must go for knowing more about the Korean. The historical site is great.

In short, Qingxi Square is a good place to enjoy nature and culture.

The Museum of Modern Art is an art museum with a lot of things to see and feel from the exterior that harmonizes the surrounding Korean atmosphere and architecture to the spacious exhibition room inside.

Ultra-modern architecture designed by Mario Pota (Mario Botta), Jean Nouvel (Jean Nouvel) and Rem Kuhas (Rem Koolhaas), which houses Korean artwork from ancient times to the present and modern artwork from abroad. Architecture and art lovers must visit. These are amazing buildings, with areas of 2/3 space. This is the most advanced technology that allows you to observe an item closer and learn more about it on your borrowed Samsung phone. No need to enter the corresponding number of the object when you are in front of an item, the phone will sense the signal and tell you information about the object until you move on. Valued celadon, antiques, plus some contemporary artwork, give people an ancient feeling. How about a black oil painting of Roscoe next to the ancient artifacts hundreds of years ago? Steel sculpture? Can you imagine this scene.

The Seoul National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art is an important art venue in Korea, with a rich collection of contemporary and contemporary art works. The museum's unique architectural design combines modern and traditional elements and complements the artworks in the museum. The exhibition in the museum covers painting, sculpture, photography, installation art and other forms, showing the latest creative achievements of artists at home and abroad. In addition, the museum regularly hosts various art events such as lectures, seminars, workshops, etc., providing visitors with more opportunities to learn and engage with art. In short, the National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art in Seoul is a worthy art hall, where art lovers and ordinary audiences can reap a rich artistic experience.

The Sejong Cultural Story Museum is located in the Guanghuamen Square in Seoul, South Korea, under the bronze statue of Sejong. The museum shows in detail the gains and losses in Sejong's governance country, especially the record of his creation of Korean text, the display is vivid and interesting, it is worth visiting.
